ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An introduction to the most central book(s) in world history (and it/they are not half bad!)

overview of the Bible, its parts, what distinguishes its parts, and their memorable passages
how to write an essay beginning from a question
how to combine literary and historical context to make arguments
In-depth knowledge of the content of the Bible, as well as how to closely read texts and look for multiple authors within a text
Understanding of the Bible as a multivocalic, diverse text. Push towards better thinking from Prof. Brisman.
I gained a solid understanding of the layout and authorship of the Bible and the contents of some of its more notable parts. I also gained experience analyzing multivocality in literature.

I received a selected (but thorough) reading of the Hebrew Bible and Christian New Testament, focusing on how the various writings within these texts point to a multitude of authors with differing views on everything from spirituality to morality to property.
In this course, I was able to develop my analytical analysis skills while also challenging my previous conception of the bible.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course could be improved by taking religious thought more seriously. It felt often like the default class attitude (perhaps in part a result of the composition of this particular group of students) was liberal-New-Athiest-y in a way that was intellectually unserious.

strengths: LB is the most kind and caring professor, themes to every class, great mix of "lecture" and guided discussion, truly a wonderful space to think about life's deepest questions
weaknesses: not much conversation between students (not so much a weakness as a feature)
improvements: not many but would be nice to occasionally review what we've done in previous classes and see what other students wrote about in their essays

The course is amazing, and the more you put into it the more you get out. There was a lot of reading, and the essays were quite difficult to write, but the content is incredible for anyone (regardless of background/knowledge of the Bible), and Professor Brisman is one of the best professors I've ever had.

Strengths: Professor Brisman, who kind, lively, caring, and blunt (in a good way). 
Weaknesses: None come to mind.

The structure of the essays needs to be rethought in this course, as it does in most English courses. Thrice a semester, we submit an essay, receive some feedback on it a few weeks later, which, if we so choose, we may never look at. There is little chance to use the instructor's expertise to improve your writing.

I really enjoyed the readings for the course, and felt they were almost always of manageable size. The seminars, led by Professor Brisman, did a great job of highlighting the important distinctions and historical context of each text, and ideas about the author(s) behind them. Class discussions were also often interesting and engaging in how they related to our contemporary lives: how modern politics resembles aspects of the Bible, or going around the room and asking each student what they thought 'morality' was.

My main feedback would be that I sometimes felt too much of class time was devoted to readings from the extracts and discussions on translations, when I sometimes would have liked to hear more about how my classmates felt about certain passages and the ideas contained within them. A lecture element is needed for this course to digestible, I understand, but I always appreciated the deviations from them (the discussion on morality) and would welcome more. Overall a great course, though!
n/a

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 111%: a course that I will remember for life

Would absolutely recommend this to another student. The professor is incredible and the Bible is even more incredible (from a literary/non-religious perspective!) and I feel so lucky to have gotten the chance to read it in this class.
Yes! Brisman has the teaching of this course down to a science, and the course attracts peers that are exciting to learn from.
Yes. Although my grade was unexpectedly low, I learned a lot about the Bible, which is a book everyone should be familiar with, and I looked forward to spending each class with Professor Brisman.

If you want to read a broad but thorough selection of the Hebrew Bible and Christian New Testament, then this class is for you! I was very curious but generally unknowledgeable about the topic going in, and felt I learned a great deal about these texts as a result--and how they were composed as 'a literature' by multiple authors over centuries. Professor Brisman is a great source of knowledge and class discussions were always a fun time!
I would recommend this course for any one who has a desire to look at problems of authorship and multivocality.

extras.title: ENGL 395 01/HUMS 380 01/LITR 154 01 - The Bible as a Literature
